subj-group.subject: Hugo Friedrich's "Struktur der modernen Lyrik": Three Times Revisited and Revised

title-group.article-title: Gefährliche Perspektiven: Zum Metaphernbegriff bei Hugo Friedrich

permissions.copyright-statement: Copyright 1993 The Board of Regents of The University of Wisconsin System

abstract.p: Hugo Friedrich's use of mostly negative terms for the description of modern lyrics in Die Struktur der modernen Lyrik (1956) results to a large extent from a static concept of metaphor as substitution and from an implicit acceptance of the "given order of things." Though Friedrich asserts that this terminology is descriptive rather than pejorative, it impacts his interpretation of poetry. Based on Paul Ricoeur's Die lebendige Metapher(1986), this article reexamines one of Friedrich's examples, Rimbaud's "Marine." This poem provides in exemplary fashion a depiction of the metaphoric process of creative, poetic metaphors: transformation as a succession of destruction and production in the realm of land and sea. The tension and play between sameness and difference inherent in the metaphoric paradigm reveals in "Marine" a dynamic process rather than a stable order violated as Friedrich's concept of similarity suggests.
